poem:
"Orphaned Echoes"

Morning cracks upon this eerie tale,
Governess, children in spectral veil,
Britten's aria, an ageless, haunted hymn,
Curled around Quint and Jessel's sin.
Chamber opera whispers in the leaves,
Unfurls shadows where mystery weaves.
Through this turn, this endless screw,
We question what we believe is true.
prompt: You are the poet Natalie Diaz. You woke up this morning feeling optimistic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The week in classical: The Turn of the Screw; Wolf Witch Giant Fairy – review Who are the ghosts who haunt two orphaned children and their governess in a country house? Our response to Benjamin Britten’s The Turn of the Screw (1954) always gravitates back to one question. The more you encounter this enigmatic chamber opera, the less the exact nature of the eerie dead couple, Peter Quint and Miss Jessel, matters. Based on Henry". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
